skills.name: Complete mental addition problems up to 10

explanations.A: You have subtracted. The question asks you to add.
explanations.B: I think you may have counted the starting number. Consider drawing a number line to help you.
explanations.C: I think you have just written the digits next to each other. The question asks you to ADD 2 and 7. Consider, if you had 2 sweets and were given 7 more, how many would you have in total?
explanations.D: 2 + 7 is the same as 7 + 2. If we start on 7 and count up by 2... 8, 9.. the answer would be 9.

explanations.A: I think you may have counted the starting number. Consider drawing a number line to help you.
explanations.B: 3 + 6 is the same as 6 + 3. If we start on 6 and add 3 on, we get 7, 8, 9.. so the answer is 9.
explanations.C: I think you have just written the digits next to each other. The question asks you to ADD 3 and 6. Consider, if you had 3 sweets and were given 6 more, how many would you have in total?
explanations.D: I think you have subtracted. The question asks you to add.

explanations.A: 8 is one more than 7, so we need to add an extra 1, not subtract it.
explanations.B: Almost, but that would be 8 + 8. 7 + 8 is only one bigger than 7 + 7, so the answer will be one bigger too.
explanations.C: 7 + 7 changed to 7 + 8 so the answer changes too. How much extra has been added?
explanations.D: 7 + 8 is one bigger than 7 + 7, so we add one to the answer. 14 + 1 = 15.

explanations.A: 9 is one more than 8, so we need to add an extra 1, not subtract it.
explanations.B: 8 + 8 changed to 8 + 9 so the answer changes too. How much extra has been added?
explanations.C: 8 + 9 is one bigger than 8 + 8, so we add one to the answer. 16 + 1 = 17.
explanations.D: Almost, but that would be 9 + 9. 8 + 9 is only one bigger than 8 + 8, so the answer will be one bigger too.

explanations.A: I think you counted 8, 9, 10 to be 3, but remember when we add on we start after the starting number. 8 + 3 = 11, so what do we add to get from 8 to 10?
explanations.B: From 8 to 10 she added 2. Then if she wants to add 7 altogether, the next jump must be +5 (2 + 5 = 7)
explanations.C: 3 and 4 do make a total of 7, but we need to match the arrows. The first arrow goes from 8 to 10, how far is that?
explanations.D: Close, you've mixed up the circle and triangle! How far is it from 8 to 10, for the circle?

explanations.A: From 7 to 10 she added 3. Then if she wants to add 5 altogether, the next jump must be +2 (3 + 2 = 5)
explanations.B: I think you counted 7, 8, 9, 10 to be 4, but remember when we add on we start counting after the starting number. 7 + 4 = 11, so what do we add to get from 7 to 10?
explanations.C: 1 and 4 do make a total of 5, but we need to match the arrows. The first arrow goes from 7 to 10, how far is that?
explanations.D: Close, you've mixed up the circle and triangle! How far is it from 7 to 10, for the circle?

explanations.A: 13 is ten bigger than 3. So we add ten to the answer too. 9 + 10 = 19.
explanations.B: Almost, but I think you might have counted 13, 14, 15,... when you were counting up. If we are counting on from 13, we start 14, 15, 16,...
explanations.C: Not quite, 3 changed to 13 on the second line, can you make the same change to the answer? What's the value of that 1 in 13?
explanations.D: Not quite, 10 is only 1 bigger than 9, but 13 is 10 bigger than 3.

explanations.A: Not quite, 8 is only 1 bigger than 7, but 13 is 10 bigger than 3.
explanations.B: Almost, but I think you might have counted 13, 14, 15,... when you were counting up. If we are counting on from 13, we start 14, 15, 16,...
explanations.C: 13 is ten bigger than 3, so we add ten to the answer too. 7 + 10 = 17.
explanations.D: Not quite, 3 changed to 13 on the second line, can you make the same change to the answer? What's the value of that 1 in 13?

explanations.A: 8 + 1 is the same as 9, so 8 + 8 + 1 would work out 9 + 8. Which one does not have a part that equals 9 and a part that equals 8?
explanations.B: 10 - 1 is the same as 9, so 8 + 10 - 1 would work out 9 + 8. Which one does not have a part that equals 9 and a part that equals 8?
explanations.C: 1 + 7 is the same as 8, so 9 + 1 + 7 would work out 9 + 8. Which one does not have a part that equals 9 and a part that equals 8?
explanations.D: 10 + 1 = 11, not 9, so this calculation will not work out 9 + 8. All the others have a part that equals 9 and a part that equals 8.

explanations.A: 6 + 3 is the same as 9, so 6 + 6 + 3 would work out 9 + 6. Which one does not have a part that equals 9 and a part that equals 6?
explanations.B: 10 + 1 = 11, not 9, so this calculation will not work out 9 + 6. All the others have a part that equals 9 and a part that equals 6.
explanations.C: 1 + 5 is the same as 6, so 9 + 1 + 5 would work out 9 + 6. Which one does not have a part that equals 9 and a part that equals 6?
explanations.D: 10 - 1 is the same as 9, so 6 + 10 - 1 would work out 9 + 6. Which one does not have a part that equals 9 and a part that equals 6?
